0.user_question: The solutions of the equation $z^4+4z^3i-6z^2-4zi-i=0$ are the vertices of a convex polygon in the complex plane.  The area of this polygon can be expressed in the form $p^{a/b},$ where $a,$ $b,$ $p$ are positive integers, $p$ is prime, and $a$ and $b$ are relatively prime.  Find $a + b + p.$

ost_step.1: To solve this quartic polynomial equation, let $w = z - i$.
ost_step.2: After substituting $w$, our new quadratic becomes $w^4 + w^3 - 6w^2 - 4iw - i = 0$.
ost_step.3: By using synthetic division or long division, we get $(w^2 + 3)(w^2 - 2w - 1) = 0$.

direct_answer.text: To begin solving, first recall De Moivre’s Theorem: $(\cos\theta + i\sin\theta)^n = \cos n\theta + i\sin n\theta$ Let us set up four equations based off of what was found above; namely when each term equals zero. Our roots would therefore come out like so:$w = -\phi ,-\omega ,\bar{\omega} ,\overline{\phi}$,where $|w| =\sqrt {(\Re (w)) ^2 + (\Im (w)) ^2 }$,$\phi : |\phi | = \sec {\pi / 6} $,and $\omega ;|\omega | = \csc {\pi / 6} $. direct_answer.text:
We start by rewriting the original equation as follows using hint provided: $$[z-(i)]^4 + [z-(i)]^3 - 6[z-(i)]^2 - 4i[(z-(i))]- [(z-(i)]=0$$Substituting $u=z-i$:$$u^4+ u^3 -6u^2-4iu -1=0$$Since every term except constant coefficient contain power higher than one unit hence it become like $$\left(\sum\limits_{k=0}^4 {4\choose k}u^{(4-k)}(-1)^{4-k}\right)+ (-4)\left(\sum\limits_{k=1}^4 {4\choose k}u^{(4-k)}(-1)^{4-k}\right)$$Now simplify above series:-<jupyter_code>from sympy import *

0.user_question: The solutions of the equation $z^4+4z^3i-6z^2-4zi-i=0$ are the vertices of a convex polygon in the complex plane.  The area of this polygon can be expressed in the form $p^{a/b},$ where $a,$ $b,$ $p$ are positive integers, $p$ is prime, and $a$ and $b$ are relatively prime.  Find $a + b + p.$

1.subquestion: Convert the imaginary coefficients to real ones using Euler's formula.

subanswer.text: Using Euler's formula, multiply every term involving $i$ by i (the magnitude squared): \[\begin{aligned}(1+i)(z^4+(iz)^3-(ix)+(iz))&=0\\ & \\ iz^4+i^2z^3+i(iz)^3+i^2(ix)-i^2z^2-i(iz)-i(iz)+i^2 &=0 \\&\\ z^4-z^3+z^2-z+1 &= 0 \end{aligned}\] So now our polynomial becomes $z^4-z^3+z^2-z+1 =0$. The answer is $z^4-z^3+z^2-z+1 =0.$

0.user_question: The solutions of the equation $z^4+4z^3i-6z^2-4zi-i=0$ are the vertices of a convex polygon in the complex plane.  The area of this polygon can be expressed in the form $p^{a/b},$ where $a,$ $b,$ $p$ are positive integers, $p$ is prime, and $a$ and $b$ are relatively prime.  Find $a + b + p.$

1.subquestion: Convert the imaginary coefficients to real ones using Euler's formula.

subanswer.text: Using Euler's formula, multiply every term involving $i$ by i (the magnitude squared): \[\begin{aligned}(1+i)(z^4+(iz)^3-(ix)+(iz))&=0\\ & \\ iz^4+i^2z^3+i(iz)^3+i^2(ix)-i^2z^2-i(iz)-i(iz)+i^2 &=0 \\&\\ z^4-z^3+z^2-z+1 &= 0 \end{aligned}\] So now our polynomial becomes $z^4-z^3+z^2-z+1 =0$. The answer is $z^4-z^3+z^2-z+1 =0.$

2.subquestion: Factorize the above equation as much as possible. Note down your factors.

subanswer.text: Letting $w=-1$, substituting yields $$w^4-w^3-w+1=(w-1)(w^3+w^2+1)=(w-1)(w-\omega)(w-\omega^2)$$where $(\omega,\omega^2)$are roots of unity which satisfy $w^4=1.$ Hence$$z^4-z^3+z^2-z+1=(z-1)(z-\omega)(z-\omega^2)(z-\omega^3)$$Since $|\omega|=|\omega^2|=|\omega^3|=1$, so wedge product $|(z-1)| |(z-\omega)| |(z-\omega^2)| |(z-\omega^3)|<2$. Therefore $$\text {Area }<\dfrac{(4r_1 r_2 )^{\frac{1}{2}} }{4}$$or less than zero since none exceed absolute maximum of three times unit circle radius or $2*\sqrt{3}>2*(\pi)$. This implies no solution exists such at least five consecutive angles formed by adjacent line segments connecting any pair among its vertexes sum up more than half turn ($90^\circ$) . Thus , if they exist must have fewer than seven edges hence cannot encompass full figure inside them.(See here ). However only quadrilateral fits criteria.* [see image](https://latex.codecogs.com/png.latex?%5Cdpi%7B120%7D%20%5Cbg_white%20%5Clarge%20%5Cbegin%7Bcaseslarr%7D%20A%20quadrilateral%20has%20at%20most%20four%20vertices%2C%5Ctimes%20%5E%7B-%5Cmathrm%7BAutomata%5CPointSetTheorem%7D%7D%5C%5C%20no%20polygon%20with%20five%20consecutive%20angles%20can%20sum%20more%20than%20half%20turn%20(%5Comega%202)&displayonly=%20yes)[Mathematica Demonstration][1]. * See

3.subquestion: Use Vieta's formulas to determine the sum and product of the roots of the quartic equation you found earlier. Include units! Hint: Write quadratic equations related to $z^4-z^3+z^2-z+1 =0$ before taking their determinants.

subanswer.text: By factorizing, $(z^4-z^3+z^2-z+1 )= (z-1)(z-\omega)(z-\omega ^2)(z-\omega^3)$, applying Vietas theorem over root sets $\{1,~\omega,~ \omega ^{2},\omega^{3}\}$, sums:\begin{array}{| l c || r|r|}&&\phantom{|}& z_1&&+\; z_2\; +\;\cdots \;+\; z_k &&=& -\tfrac{q_{k}}{p}\\ &&1 &&+ \tfrac{-1}{\pm W} &&=~~~ &\rightarrow ~~~ 1 \; =\; \tfrac{-1}{\pm W} ~\Longrightarrow~~~~~~~~~~~~~W=\pm 1\end{array}While products:$[\prod _j \, {z_i}^{m_j}]={z}^{\underline {\displaystyle m}}=~\ldots~$and$\begin{align*} \left({z}^4-{z}^3+{z}^2-{z}+1\right)\left[{z}^{-3}-{z}^{-1}+{z}^{-4}-{z}^{-3}+1\right]\ &=\left[({z}^2-z+1){z}^{(2)}-z\right]\left[{z}^{-4}-{z}^{-2}+{z}^{-1}-1\right]=\\=[\,]{z}^{-7}-{z}^{-6}+{z}^{-5}-\frac{{z}^{-4}}{2}\,\right],\,\,\, [{z}^{6}-2{z}^{5}+\frac{3}{2}\,{z}^{4}-{z}^{3}+2\,{z}^{2}-3\,z+2]\\={\bf I}_{1}\left( {{u}^{7}}\!\right),\end{align*}$so ${\bf P}_4 := [-I_1({\bf u}^7)]^{-1}$is obtained via Cayley Hamilton Theorem:\\${-1}/\{-\frac{{\bf q}_1}{{\bf p}_1}\}\equiv -[-I_1({\bf v}^7)]^{-1}$whose right hand side equals left handed side after some manipulations.<hr/>**Note**:[This content requires MathJax installed but not enabled.](http://www.mathjaxusers.org/)
